# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- Main code lives in `spec-kit/src/specify_cli/__init__.py`; CLI entrypoint is `specify`.
- Templates that drive generated projects are in `spec-kit/templates/` (commands, tasks, prompts, etc.).
- Helper scripts for contributors are in `spec-kit/scripts/` (bash and PowerShell variants); docs and guides sit in `spec-kit/docs/`.
- Governance memory (e.g., `spec-kit/memory/constitution.md`) guides agents; update when process changes.
- Media/assets live in `spec-kit/media/`; published changelog and policies sit alongside (`CHANGELOG.md`, `CONTRIBUTING.md`, `SECURITY.md`).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- First-time setup: `cd spec-kit && uv sync` (Python 3.11+ required).
- Fast local run without install: `cd spec-kit && python -m src.specify_cli --help` or `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools --script sh`.
- Editable install: `cd spec-kit && uv pip install -e .` then `specify ...` is available on PATH.
- Simulate end-user flow from the current branch: `cd spec-kit && uvx --from . specify init demo-uvx --ai claude --ignore-agent-tools`.
- Package check: `cd spec-kit && uv build` (outputs to `dist/`).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Python code uses 4-space indent, type hints, and Typer commands with rich output; follow existing command patterns and helper utilities in `specify_cli`.
- Keep option/flag names kebab-case for the CLI and snake_case in Python; prefer small, composable functions over new globals.
- Templates are prefixed with `speckit.` and scripts use hyphenated names (e.g., `create-new-feature.sh`); match these patterns when adding files.
- Linting is light; keep imports tidy and run `python -c "import specify_cli"` for a quick sanity check.

## Testing Guidelines
- There is no automated test suite today; run smoke flows after changes:
  - `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools` in a temp directory.
  - Verify generated scripts are executable (`ls -l scripts/*.sh`) and Windows-friendly (`.ps1` present).
- Adjust `templates/` and docs when behavior changes; manual validation is expected before PRs.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Discuss large template/CLI changes with maintainers before opening a PR. Work on feature branches (`git checkout -b feature-name`).
- Commit messages should be clear and scoped; update `CHANGELOG.md` when altering user-facing behavior.
- PRs should describe intent, testing performed, and impacted templates/scripts; link related issues and screenshots/logs when relevant.
- Document any AI assistance in the PR (per `CONTRIBUTING.md`), ensure docs (`README.md`, `spec-driven.md`, `docs/*.md`) stay in sync, and avoid committing secrets (tokens like `GH_TOKEN` are for local use only).

# GM‑Kit: Spec‑Driven MCP Toolkit for TTRPG Session Prep

GM‑Kit is a spec‑driven toolkit (inspired by GitHub’s Spec‑Kit) that helps Game Masters prepare sessions quickly and flexibly. It is system‑agnostic and story‑first, organizing prep around the three pillars of TTRPG play: Combat, Exploration, and Social encounters.

## Vision
- Make prep fast and focused: generate just enough structure for the next session.
- Keep story first: emphasize stakes, consequences, clues, and factions over mechanics.
- Stay system‑agnostic: never emit rules text; reference “Stat Sources” instead.
- Be Obsidian‑friendly: one session packet (Markdown) that links all artifacts.
- Published Scenario Ingestion: convert PDFs into clean, linked, GM‑ready prep with minimal effort.
- Visual Story Maps: generate DOT graphs to navigate branches and consequences.

## Guiding Principles (Baseline Constitution)
- System‑Agnostic, Story‑First: Use Stat Source pointers (book/page/link) instead of rules.
- One page encounter sructure as per best practices.
- Prep Only What’s Needed Next (Lazy DM): Target 3–6 scenes; avoid over‑prep.
- Obsidian‑Friendly Markdown: Frontmatter, relative links, and stable naming.
- Licensing & Provenance: Record title/author/publication/license; default outputs to private‑use; avoid bundling protected assets.

## Core Artifacts
- Combat Encounter: Objective; battlefield/terrain; participants (Stat Source); tactics/dials; morale; consequences; rewards; assets; prep checklist.
- Exploration Encounter: Area concept; sensory details; points of interest; obstacles/traps/hazards; secrets & clues; skill triggers; stakes; timers/clocks; map/handouts; prep checklist.
- Social Encounter: Stakes & desired outcomes; key NPCs (desires/levers/secrets/voices; Stat Source); clues; techniques (compels/bargains); failure states; rewards; prep checklist.
- NPC: Role; goals/levers; secrets; relationships; voice; Stat Source; tactics/parley; notes.
- Monster: Role; tactics; terrain; morale; Stat Source; complications/clocks; loot/clues.
- Trap: Fictional cues; trigger; effect; countermeasures; consequences; Stat Source.
- Faction: Goal; methods; assets; relationships; fronts/threats; clocks; upcoming moves.
- Clock: Name; segments (4/6/8); advances when; on completion; related scenes/NPCs; current.
- Session Packet: Single Markdown outline with frontmatter, scenes, quick refs, pull list, prep checklist, post‑session delta.
- Scenario Ingest: scenario.md (cleaned Markdown) + images/
- Distilled Notes: distilled.md (GM shorthand bullets)
- Plot Graph: plot.dot (+ optional image)
- Obsidian Outline: outline.md
- Mapping Report: alignment-report.md

## Command Set (MCP‑Style)
- Creation (focused): gmkit.encounter.{combat|exploration|social}, gmkit.npc, gmkit.monster, gmkit.trap, gmkit.faction, gmkit.clock.
- Router: gmkit.specify — classifies a prompt and creates the right artifact; asks one disambiguation question if needed.
- Prep/Review: gmkit.clarify (≤3 questions; writes back), gmkit.analyze (read‑only report), gmkit.checklist (artifact/session quality gates).
- Session Assembly: gmkit.session — produces a single Obsidian‑friendly Markdown packet for the next session.
- Export (v1): gmkit.export — confirm session + assets are linkable; Markdown‑only.
- Scenario Conversion:
  - Ingestion: gmkit.ingest.pdf
  - Distillation: gmkit.distill.scenario
  - Plot Graph: gmkit.visigraph
  - Scenario Analysis (read‑only): gmkit.analyze.scenario
  - Obsidian Outline: gmkit.outline.scenario
  - Alignment: gmkit.align.scenario
  - Orchestrator: gmkit.convert.scenario

## Flows
- Idea → Artifact: One‑line prompt becomes a pillar encounter/NPC/etc. via a focused command or gmkit.specify router.
- Clarify: Ask up to three targeted questions; write back to the artifact.
- Session: Assemble a session packet from selected artifacts; keep scenes/assets minimal.
- Analyze: Read‑only consistency check (orphans, clocks, links, over‑prep).
- Checklist: Short, practical QA that acts as “unit tests for English.”
- Scenario Ingestion Pipeline: PDF → scenario.md → distilled.md → plot.dot → analysis report → outline.md → align into artifacts → optional session.md.
- Session‑First Constraint: select only what’s needed for next session; warn on over‑prep (too many scenes/assets).

## File/Linking Policy (Obsidian)
- YAML frontmatter on the session packet (title, date, session number, tags).
- Relative links only; kebab‑case names; numbered folders inside each feature to avoid collisions.
- Keep node IDs in plot.dot synchronized with artifact short names where feasible.
- No rules content; always use Stat Source pointers.

## Prerequisites (CLI)
- qpdf, poppler-utils (pdfinfo/pdftohtml/pdfimages), pandoc, graphviz, ocrmypdf (optional), mutool (optional).
- gm-kit init should check these and print install hints per OS.

## Non‑Goals (v1)
- No system stat generation; no PDF/zip export (Markdown‑only for now).
- No GM “acting” or live adjudication features; this is prep support, not runtime GMing.

## Success Metrics
- A one‑line idea reliably becomes a usable artifact with clear sections.
- A single session packet is generated with valid links, ready to run a game.
- Clarify reduces ambiguity in one short interaction.
- Analyze/checklist catches issues before a session without being heavy‑weight.
- Ingestion: ≤5% structural noise post‑ingest; Distillation: ≥70% time reduction; Graph: ≥95% correct branch representation; zero broken links in outline/alignment.

## Implementation Notes (for future specs)
- Follow Spec‑Kit’s two‑step pattern where applicable: scripts handle file ops; commands handle content.
- Keep templates terse and evocative; bias toward “usable tonight.”
- Enforce “prep only next session” through nudges and warnings, not hard blocks.
- Orchestrator should summarize each stage and confirm continuation.

-# GM‑Kit: Spec‑Driven MCP Toolkit for TTRPG Session Prep
-
-GM‑Kit is a spec‑driven toolkit (inspired by GitHub’s Spec‑Kit) that helps Game Masters prepare sessions quickly and flexibly. It is system‑agnostic and story‑first, organizing prep around the three pillars of TTRPG play: Combat, Exploration, and Social encounters.
-
-## Vision
-- Make prep fast and focused: generate just enough structure for the next session.
-- Keep story first: emphasize stakes, consequences, clues, and factions over mechanics.
-- Stay system‑agnostic: never emit rules text; reference “Stat Sources” instead.
-- Be Obsidian‑friendly: one session packet (Markdown) that links all artifacts.
-- Published Scenario Ingestion: convert PDFs into clean, linked, GM‑ready prep with minimal effort.
-- Visual Story Maps: generate DOT graphs to navigate branches and consequences.
-
-## Guiding Principles (Baseline Constitution)
-- System‑Agnostic, Story‑First: Use Stat Source pointers (book/page/link) instead of rules.
-- One page encounter sructure as per best practices.
-- Prep Only What’s Needed Next (Lazy DM): Target 3–6 scenes; avoid over‑prep.
-- Obsidian‑Friendly Markdown: Frontmatter, relative links, and stable naming.
-- Licensing & Provenance: Record title/author/publication/license; default outputs to private‑use; avoid bundling protected assets.
-
-## Core Artifacts
-- Combat Encounter: Objective; battlefield/terrain; participants (Stat Source); tactics/dials; morale; consequences; rewards; assets; prep checklist.
-- Exploration Encounter: Area concept; sensory details; points of interest; obstacles/traps/hazards; secrets & clues; skill triggers; stakes; timers/clocks; map/handouts; prep checklist.
-- Social Encounter: Stakes & desired outcomes; key NPCs (desires/levers/secrets/voices; Stat Source); clues; techniques (compels/bargains); failure states; rewards; prep checklist.
-- NPC: Role; goals/levers; secrets; relationships; voice; Stat Source; tactics/parley; notes.
-- Monster: Role; tactics; terrain; morale; Stat Source; complications/clocks; loot/clues.
-- Trap: Fictional cues; trigger; effect; countermeasures; consequences; Stat Source.
-- Faction: Goal; methods; assets; relationships; fronts/threats; clocks; upcoming moves.
-- Clock: Name; segments (4/6/8); advances when; on completion; related scenes/NPCs; current.
-- Session Packet: Single Markdown outline with frontmatter, scenes, quick refs, pull list, prep checklist, post‑session delta.
-- Scenario Ingest: scenario.md (cleaned Markdown) + images/
-- Distilled Notes: distilled.md (GM shorthand bullets)
-- Plot Graph: plot.dot (+ optional image)
-- Obsidian Outline: outline.md
-- Mapping Report: alignment-report.md
-
-## Command Set (MCP‑Style)
-- Creation (focused): gmkit.encounter.{combat|exploration|social}, gmkit.npc, gmkit.monster, gmkit.trap, gmkit.faction, gmkit.clock.
-- Router: gmkit.specify — classifies a prompt and creates the right artifact; asks one disambiguation question if needed.
-- Prep/Review: gmkit.clarify (≤3 questions; writes back), gmkit.analyze (read‑only report), gmkit.checklist (artifact/session quality gates).
-- Session Assembly: gmkit.session — produces a single Obsidian‑friendly Markdown packet for the next session.
-- Export (v1): gmkit.export — confirm session + assets are linkable; Markdown‑only.
-- Scenario Conversion:
-  - Ingestion: gmkit.ingest.pdf
-  - Distillation: gmkit.distill.scenario
-  - Plot Graph: gmkit.visigraph
-  - Scenario Analysis (read‑only): gmkit.analyze.scenario
-  - Obsidian Outline: gmkit.outline.scenario
-  - Alignment: gmkit.align.scenario
-  - Orchestrator: gmkit.convert.scenario
-
-## Flows
-- Idea → Artifact: One‑line prompt becomes a pillar encounter/NPC/etc. via a focused command or gmkit.specify router.
-- Clarify: Ask up to three targeted questions; write back to the artifact.
-- Session: Assemble a session packet from selected artifacts; keep scenes/assets minimal.
-- Analyze: Read‑only consistency check (orphans, clocks, links, over‑prep).
-- Checklist: Short, practical QA that acts as “unit tests for English.”
-- Scenario Ingestion Pipeline: PDF → scenario.md → distilled.md → plot.dot → analysis report → outline.md → align into artifacts → optional session.md.
-- Session‑First Constraint: select only what’s needed for next session; warn on over‑prep (too many scenes/assets).
-
-## File/Linking Policy (Obsidian)
-- YAML frontmatter on the session packet (title, date, session number, tags).
-- Relative links only; kebab‑case names; numbered folders inside each feature to avoid collisions.
-- Keep node IDs in plot.dot synchronized with artifact short names where feasible.
-- No rules content; always use Stat Source pointers.
-
-## Prerequisites (CLI)
-- qpdf, poppler-utils (pdfinfo/pdftohtml/pdfimages), pandoc, graphviz, ocrmypdf (optional), mutool (optional).
-- gm-kit init should check these and print install hints per OS.
-
-## Non‑Goals (v1)
-- No system stat generation; no PDF/zip export (Markdown‑only for now).
-- No GM “acting” or live adjudication features; this is prep support, not runtime GMing.
-
-## Success Metrics
-- A one‑line idea reliably becomes a usable artifact with clear sections.
-- A single session packet is generated with valid links, ready to run a game.
-- Clarify reduces ambiguity in one short interaction.
-- Analyze/checklist catches issues before a session without being heavy‑weight.
-- Ingestion: ≤5% structural noise post‑ingest; Distillation: ≥70% time reduction; Graph: ≥95% correct branch representation; zero broken links in outline/alignment.
-
-## Implementation Notes (for future specs)
-- Follow Spec‑Kit’s two‑step pattern where applicable: scripts handle file ops; commands handle content.
-- Keep templates terse and evocative; bias toward “usable tonight.”
-- Enforce “prep only next session” through nudges and warnings, not hard blocks.
-- Orchestrator should summarize each stage and confirm continuation.

+GM-Kit is a spec-driven toolkit built with Spec-Kit's MCP workflow that helps Game Masters restructure adventures into Kelsey Dionne's Arcane Library format. +## Vision
+- Convert any scenario (PDFs, prior notes, or scratch ideas) into Arcane Library style prep the GM can trust at the table.
+- Keep prep lightweight: todos → prompts → specs → plans → tasks → implementation is the required workflow across every improvement.
+- Stay system-agnostic: reference Stat Sources or provenance instead of embedding mechanics.

+
+## Arcane Library Standard
+Arcane Library one-page beats are the canonical schema:
+- **Frontmatter packet**: Synopsis, Background, Word to the GM (boilerplate), and Pacing/Transitions guidance.
